author: By Davey Alba
title: Russia has been laying groundwork online for a ‘false flag’ operation, misinformation researchers say.
description: Several claims have circulated on social media, often after they are mentioned by Russian officials or news media.
content: At the White House this week, President Biden said the United States had “reason to believe” that Russia was “engaged in a false flag operation” to use as an excuse to invade Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: Alexandra Burghardt is a favorite in a winter sport she picked up in September.
description: Alexandra Burghardt adjusted her new Winter Olympics outfit in a hotel a few miles away from the bobsledding track in the mountains outside Beijing.
content: Alexandra Burghardt adjusted her new Winter Olympics outfit in a hotel a few miles away from the bobsledding track in the mountains outside Beijing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Peter Earnest, C.I.A. Veteran Who Ran a Spy Museum, Dies at 88
description: He ran secret agents and later served as the agency’s spokesman. Both roles prepared him well for his role as the International Spy Museum’s first director.
content: Peter Earnest, who spent decades running undercover operatives for the C.I.A. during the Cold War and later drew on that expertise as the first executive director of the International Spy Museum in Washington, died on Feb. 13 in a hospital in Arlington, Va. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes and Eric Schmitt
title: Counting Russian troops is an imprecise science.
description: American officials said a new troop estimate includes some forces that were not previously counted — most notably Russian forces in Crimea, as well as separatist forces in the Donbas region.
content: The United States now believes that Russia has as many as 190,000 troops in or near Ukraine, nearly twice as many as there were in January, according to an assessment made public on Friday by Michael Carpenter, the U.S. ambassador to the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: After 24 years, the four-man Jamaican bobsled team is back.
description: For the first time since the 1998 Winter Games, Jamaica has a four-man bobsled team in the Olympics.
content: When the Jamaican four-man bobsled team made their Olympic debut in 1988, the story went on to inspire the much adored Disney film “Cool Runnings” — and the unlikely underdogs from Jamaica helped familiarize the unique sport for the masses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Coaston
title: It’s Easy to Put ‘Jesus’ on Your Bus. Practicing Faith Is Harder.
description: Kandiss Taylor takes us to a new low with her campaign wheels.
content: On Thursday, I saw tweets featuring the debut of a campaign bus for Kandiss Taylor, a Republican candidate for governor of Georgia. It is emblazoned with what is evidently her platform: “Jesus, Guns, Babies.” That’s it. No further explanation needed, or perhaps more accurately, no further explanation given.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Unequal Enforcement Led Officials to Repeal a Seattle Helmet Law
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, February 19, 2022.
content: “The question before us was whether a helmet law that’s enforced by police on balance produces results that outweigh the harm that that law creates.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yousur Al-Hlou, Masha Froliak, Brent McDonald and Dmitriy Khavin
title: Ukraine’s paramilitaries prepare for conflict with Russia.
description: Times journalists followed the members of one such group
content: MARIUPOL, UKRAINE — Paramilitary groups are actively preparing for a Russian invasion near Ukraine’s front line with Russia-backed separatists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: What to Watch This Weekend
description: The two releases of “Cape Fear” couldn’t be more different — and it’s what makes them so revealing.
content: One of my projects for this year is to finally watch every film in Martin Scorsese’s filmography. Last week, we got to “Cape Fear,” his 1991 thriller and immediate follow-up to “Goodfellas.” But before watching Scorsese’s “Cape Fear,” I wanted to watch the original 1962 film, starring Gregory Peck, Robert Mitchum, Polly Bergen and Martin Balsam, and directed by J. Lee Thompson.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simbarashe Cha and Elizabeth Bristow
title: New York Fashion Week Style:
description: A photographer’s sidewalk view of style around the fashion shows.
content: I remember the first time I walked up the steps to New York Fashion Week at Lincoln Center a decade ago, armed with my camera and a new zoom lens I purchased just for this occasion. I had no expectations except for the fact that a friend of mine thought it would be a nice boost to my growing love for collecting portraits of strangers on the streets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kimmelman
title: When Architects Made Worlds
description: MoMA explores an era of sweeping change, when South Asian architects — pioneering women, among them — redefined the postcolonial era and helped construct new nation states.
content: Back in the 1950s, the architect Minnette de Silva pioneered a new version of the modern house in Ceylon. She floated living quarters above gardens on slender concrete pilotis. She conjured up airy interiors of fluid space for family gatherings and Buddhist ceremonies, the rooms circulating around a sweeping staircase, the building made with homegrown timbers like jak and halmilla.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora and Mark Landler
title: Zelensky leaves Ukraine, heading to Munich to rally Western support.
description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine chose not to cancel his scheduled trip out of the country Saturday to attend a security conference in Munich, even as warnings from the West about a Russian invasion of his country grew increasingly urgent.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine chose not to cancel his scheduled trip out of the country Saturday to attend a security conference in Munich, even as warnings from the West about a Russian invasion of his country grew increasingly urgent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: A New Class War Comes to Canada
description: In the trucker protests, it’s meritocrats versus populists and the virtual against the physical.
content: A great and mostly unknown prophet of our time is Michael Young, whose book “The Rise of the Meritocracy,” published way back in 1958, both coined the term in its title and predicted, in its fictional vision of the 21st century, meritocracy’s unhappy destination: not the serene rule of the deserving and talented, but a society where a ruling class selected for intelligence but defined by arrogance and insularity faces a roiling populism whose grievances shift but whose anger at the new class order is a constant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Rodent Infestation at Family Dollar Warehouse Leads to Hundreds of Closures
description: F.D.A. inspectors said that a fumigation of the West Memphis, Ark., distribution center last month revealed more than 1,100 dead rodents. A far-reaching recall has been issued for stores in six states.
content: The value-store chain Family Dollar said on Saturday that it had temporarily closed more than 400 stores after the discovery of a rodent infestation and other unsanitary conditions at a distribution center in Arkansas touched off a far-reaching recall of food, dietary supplements, cosmetics and other products.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corey Kilgannon
title: The Battle Over Race, Tradition and an Elite Private School’s Mascot
description: Collegiate’s Dutchman character got a makeover after students demanded the exclusive Manhattan school “address its own problems with racism and intolerance.”
content: The national reckoning over race and privilege that has caused upheaval at schools across the country arrived at Collegiate, one of New York City’s most prestigious private schools, when a group of students of color publicly demanded that the 400-year-old institution “address its own problems with racism and intolerance.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Hagelin and Gillian Silverman
title: Why We Love Lazy, Drunk, Broke Women on TV
description: The “unbecoming” heroine is a timely reminder that women need not be responsible, self-improving and productive in order to be valued.
content: When we meet Sam, the 40-something protagonist of the HBO dramedy “Somebody Somewhere,” she has returned to her hometown, Manhattan, Kan., to care for her dying sister — and finds herself stuck there, single, unhappy, struggling with aging parents and a dead-end job. While her other sister runs a tchotchkes shop and her friend Joel creates vision boards, Sam seems to be moving away from, rather than toward, the objects of middle-class aspiration: marriage, children, job security.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: If My Lease Expired but I’m Still Paying Rent, Can I Be Kicked Out?
description: When leases end but tenants stay, they continue under a month-to-month rental agreement based on the terms of the original lease.
content: Q: I have been renting an apartment in an eight-unit building in Brooklyn for six years. After my initial one-year lease expired, I was never given a renewal. In all these years, my rent has never increased, which is remarkable in my trendy neighborhood where I’ve seen friends move out due to rent hikes. This has been an amazing deal, but in the back of my mind, I’ve always been nervous that I have no protection and the landlord could make me leave on a whim. What protections, if any, do I have?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Fielding
title: Overlooked No More: Mary Eliza Mahoney, Who Opened Doors in Nursing
description: As the first trained Black nurse in America, Mahoney devoted her life to creating opportunities in the profession for people of all races.
content: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Kelly and Erin Schaff
title: One of the Infrastructure Plan’s Biggest Winners Is the Pavement You Drive On
description: A range of special interests lobbied for infrastructure dollars. The asphalt industry may have been the most successful.
content: In the middle of the infrastructure bill negotiations last year, with the pandemic still limiting in-person meetings, the lobbyist Martin T. Whitmer Jr. found a creative way to get in front of lawmakers with a message from his client, the asphalt industry: He pulled a pair of collapsible lawn chairs out of his trunk and invited lawmakers to meet with him in a park near the Capitol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: Shelling Escalates in Ukraine as Thousands Flee, Fearing Attack
description: Western leaders repeat calls for a diplomatic resolution to the crisis. Russia fires missiles in a blunt warning of where the conflict could lead.
content: Artillery fire escalated sharply in eastern Ukraine on Saturday and thousands of residents fled the region in chaotic evacuations — two developments rife with opportunities for what the United States has warned could be a pretext for a Russian invasion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliet Macur
title: U.S. figure skaters are rejected in a bid to be awarded their team medals.
description: Nine American skaters asked the court to order the I.O.C. to award their silver medals from the event, the results of which have been in doubt since Kamila Valieva of Russia was found to have failed a drug test.
content: The Court of Arbitration for Sport on Saturday rejected an effort by nine American figure skaters who were seeking to receive their silver medals from the ill-fated team competition at the Beijing Olympics before they left China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan
title: The U.S. surgeon general and his family have Covid, a reminder of Omicron’s stealthy threat.
description: The doctor and his wife tested positive after caring for their two sick children.
content: Dr. Vivek H. Murthy, the U.S. surgeon general, and his family have tested positive for the coronavirus. Dr. Murthy said Friday that he and his wife had mild symptoms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: An Earlier Trek to Ottawa Had a Different Tone but Still Captured the Nation
description: Deep in the Great Depression, about 1,000 men attempted to reach Ottawa to reform relief programs. Most didn’t make it but they eventually achieved their aims.
content: On Friday afternoon there were two starkly different views from the Fairmont Chateau Laurier hotel in Ottawa, where I’ve been working. Immediately out front, hundreds of angry protesters were alternately shouting a mix of abuses and pleas for law enforcement to leave and singing “O Canada” following a daylong effort by a mass of police officers to push them out of a truck blockade that had particularly snarled traffic. But from my room’s window looking toward the heart of the anti-vaccine trucker blockade on Parliament, protesters were relatively scarce as the truck drivers revved their engines and honked their horns, apparently in warning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins, Maria Varenikova and Marc Santora
title: As warnings of war grow louder, Ukrainians try to keep their bearings.
description: The crisis has taken a toll on many Ukrainians.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — Every February seems to be difficult for Julia Po. It is the month she had to leave her home in Crimea in 2014 after Russian troops annexed it and pro-Moscow separatists took control of parts of eastern Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg and Matthew Futterman
title: Mikaela Shiffrin’s final race, the mixed team event, is postponed.
description: The event is the only mixed-gender ski racing event at the Winter Games.
content: Mikaela Shiffrin came into the Beijing Olympics with the goal of competing in five events. She did so, though she fell short of her larger ambitions, failing to finish three races and placing ninth and 18th in two others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: U.S. prime-time broadcast coverage includes Alpine skiing, figure skating and hockey.
description: USA Network airs the mixed team Alpine skiing event, where Mikaela Shiffrin has her last chance to win a medal in Beijing.
content: The U.S. broadcast coverage of the Winter Games continues on Saturday with Alpine skiing, pairs figure skating and the gold medal game in men’s hockey. All times are Eastern.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christoph Koettl, Brenna Smith, Haley Willis and Masha Froliak
title: Videos show reported explosions near Luhansk.
description: Two explosions were reported Friday near the city of Luhansk, capping off a volatile day in the pro-Moscow separatist regions of Donetsk and Luhansk in eastern Ukraine.
content: Two explosions were reported Friday near the city of Luhansk, capping off a volatile day in the pro-Moscow separatist regions of Donetsk and Luhansk in eastern Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Fears grow in eastern Ukraine as shelling picks up in recent days.
description: Artillery shells struck a ring of front-line towns in eastern Ukraine on Friday, blowing out windows, hitting schools, homes and military positions — and stirring fears that the escalation is a prelude to direct Russian military action.
content: Artillery shells struck a ring of front-line towns in eastern Ukraine on Friday, blowing out windows, hitting schools, homes and military positions — and stirring fears that the escalation is a prelude to direct Russian military action.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: The Olympic gender gap is closing, but work remains.
description: Women say they are seeking equality of opportunity, not necessarily equal outcomes.
content: Eileen Gu made history this week when she became the first freestyle skier to win three medals at a single Olympics, capping a stunning performance in Beijing with a gold in the women’s halfpipe on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: ‘Botheration!’
description: Billy Bratton’s Saturday puzzle has fangs.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — I like the four corners of this grid well enough, but it’s really all about the windmill in the center, which is Billy Bratton’s point of pride in his second puzzle for The Times (see his notes below). I tilted at that windmill more than once before figuring out the whole set, although solvers with senses of humor that are skewed to just the right angle probably struggled less. I find that kind of challenge really fun — I’ve never outgrown the urge to “get” a joke and fit in with the cool kids, and the center-most cross of that windmill includes two examples of that sardonic wit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Why Ukraine Matters: What to Know About the Crisis With Russia
description: Here’s how the country ended up at the center of a global crisis.
content: On the edge of Europe and thousands of miles from the United States, the relevance of Ukraine extends far beyond its borders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Can Dems Dodge Doomsday?
description: Democratic gurus warn party to get real, real fast.
content: It may be a TikTok world, but sometimes old hacks know best.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophie Kasakove
title: Seattle Bike Helmet Rule Is Dropped Amid Racial Justice Concerns
description: Analysis showed that the King County regulation was enforced disproportionately against homeless people and people of color. Critics say the repeal will jeopardize safety.
content: In Seattle, home to one of the largest populations of bike commuters in the country, officials have overturned a decades-old regulation requiring cyclists to wear helmets because of what they called discriminatory enforcement of the rule against homeless people and people of color.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kayla Stewart
title: The Ebony Test Kitchen, Where Black Cuisine Was Celebrated, Is Reborn
description: The vibrant room is the centerpiece of a new exhibition in Harlem focused on the African American food experience.
content: When Charlotte Lyons first stepped into the Ebony test kitchen in Chicago after becoming the magazine’s food editor in 1985, one thought ran through her mind: “Whoa!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg and Illustrations by Tim Peacock
title: Should You Still Wear a Mask?
description: Experts weigh in on where, and when, you can safely take one off.
content: As masking mandates lift and new coronavirus infections fall across the United States, there’s lots of confusion about if, and when, to wear a mask.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger and Andrew E. Kramer
title: President Zelensky asks the West to make no deals ‘behind our back’ as the threat to Ukraine grows.
description: MUNICH — As shelling hammered towns in eastern Ukraine on Saturday and civilians boarded buses to evacuate the region, Russia engaged in a dramatic display of military theater, test-firing ballistic and cruise missiles in a reminder to the West that a conflict over Ukraine could quickly escalate.
content: MUNICH — As shelling hammered towns in eastern Ukraine on Saturday and civilians boarded buses to evacuate the region, Russia engaged in a dramatic display of military theater, test-firing ballistic and cruise missiles in a reminder to the West that a conflict over Ukraine could quickly escalate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Ex-Modeling Agent and Epstein Associate Found Dead in a Paris Jail
description: Jean-Luc Brunel had been charged with the rape of minors and was suspected of scouting young girls for Jeffrey Epstein.
content: PARIS — A former French modeling agent who had been charged with the rape of minors and was suspected of scouting young women for the disgraced financier Jeffrey Epstein was found dead in his Paris jail cell, a spokesman for the Paris prosecutor said on Saturday, in what appeared to be a suicide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder and Talya Minsberg
title: Two Americans take medals in the freestyle skiing halfpipe.
description: David Wise earned the silver and Alex Ferreira the bronze. Nico Porteous of New Zealand won gold.
content: The United States captured a pair of medals in men’s freestyle skiing halfpipe on Saturday in Zhangjiakou, defying gravity as much as Hebei Province’s punishing, snow-and-wind-blown conditions would allow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Overnight broadcast coverage includes figure skating and bobsledding.
description: The pairs skating event ends tonight, and the top Chinese duo are in the lead.
content: The U.S. broadcast coverage of the 2022 Winter Games continues overnight on Sunday. All times are Eastern.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval
title: How the Fight Over Abortion Rights Has Changed the Politics of South Texas
description: In the Laredo region, long a Democratic stronghold, that single issue appears to be driving the decision for many voters, the majority of whom are Catholic.
content: LAREDO, Texas — Like the majority of her neighbors in the heavily Latino community of Laredo, Angelica Garza has voted for Democrats for most of her adult life. Her longtime congressman, Henry Cuellar, with his moderate views and opposition to abortion, made it an easy choice, she said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: In Ukraine Crisis, the Looming Threat of a New Cold War
description: If he invades, President Vladimir V. Putin is inviting a new global struggle with the West. He should think about how the last one ended, analysts say.
content: MOSCOW — Vladimir Pozner was an English-language Soviet propaganda editor in Moscow in 1962, a job that gave him rare access to American newspapers and magazines. That allowed him to follow the Cuban Missile Crisis outside the Soviet media filter, and sense a world at the brink of war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: Shelling escalates in eastern Ukraine, as U.S. officials warn of pretexts for a Russian invasion.
description: Artillery fire escalated sharply in eastern Ukraine on Saturday and thousands of residents fled the region in chaotic evacuations — two developments rife with opportunities for what the United States has warned could be a pretext for a Russian invasion.
content: Artillery fire escalated sharply in eastern Ukraine on Saturday and thousands of residents fled the region in chaotic evacuations — two developments rife with opportunities for what the United States has warned could be a pretext for a Russian invasion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: How Life Resumes
description: We can wait for normal life to return, or we can just start living.
content: The 7 p.m. screening of “The Worst Person in the World” at the cinema down the street was pretty packed the other night. Couples on dates, groups of friends, solo showgoers who got there early to snag good seats. How many were seeing their first movie outside the house in months, or years?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: In Munich, Kamala Harris says the West faces a ‘defining moment.’
description: The vice president’s first public remarks on the Ukraine crisis were watched with scrutiny.
content: MUNICH — Vice President Kamala Harris told the Munich Security Conference on Saturday that the Western alliance faced a “defining moment” in the Ukraine crisis and warned Russia’s leaders that if they invaded Ukraine, the United States and its allies would target not only financial institutions and technology exports to Russia, but also “those who are complicit and those who aid and direct this unprovoked invasion.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Viviana A. Zelizer
title: When We Were Socially Distant, Money Brought Us Closer
description: Despite economic turmoil and physical danger, charitable giving went up during the pandemic. Why?
content: As the Covid-19 pandemic shattered lives and livelihoods, experts somberly anticipated a decline in philanthropic donations. The World Bank predicted an alarming drop of 20 percent in global emigrant remittances as a result of the economic crisis. After all, the 2008 Great Recession led to reductions in charitable giving as well as a downturn in those crucial monetary transfers that immigrants send home. Yet remarkably, both forecasts failed, as monetary donations surged during the early days of the pandemic and the flow of immigrant remittances proved resilient.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: In Twilight of Life, Civil Rights Activists Feel ‘Urgency to Tell Our History’
description: Young people who marched and organized during the civil rights movement are now in their 70s and 80s. With fewer and fewer remaining, historians rush to record their stories.
content: The oral historians’ camera turned on. Vivian Washington Filer looked up, facing the lens. After decades of waiting, here was her chance to set the record straight in Gainesville, Fla. — to share what it had taken for her and a friend to integrate an Alachua County doctor’s office in 1964.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: What’s left? Five final golds, and then the closing ceremony.
description: The final day of competition will have an abbreviated schedule.
content: The final day of the Winter Olympics on Sunday will have an abbreviated schedule, with only five medal events, all taking place during the evening hours on Saturday in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David D. Kirkpatrick
title: Who Is Behind QAnon? Linguistic Detectives Find Fingerprints
description: Using machine learning, separate teams of computer scientists identified the same two men as likely authors of messages that fueled the viral movement.
content: “Open your eyes,” the online post began, claiming, “Many in our govt worship Satan.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Vrentas
title: Steelers Hire Brian Flores as an Assistant Amid His N.F.L. Lawsuit
description: The former Dolphins head coach who has accused the league and its 32 teams of discriminatory hiring practices against Black coaches will join the Steelers as a senior defensive assistant linebackers coach.
content: Brian Flores, the former Miami Dolphins coach who is suing the N.F.L. and its 32 teams alleging discriminatory hiring practices toward Black candidates, was hired by the Pittsburgh Steelers as a senior defensive assistant/linebackers coach, the team announced on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: U.S. Lifts Temporary Ban on Avocados From Mexico
description: The ban was issued last week after a U.S. inspector was verbally threatened in the state of Michoacán in Mexico.
content: The United States lifted a temporary ban on avocados from Mexico on Friday, allowing exports of the fruit to resume, the U.S. Department of Agriculture said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: Two Olympics in Six Months: How Alexandra Burghardt Sprinted to the Winter Games
description: Within weeks of competing in Tokyo, Burghardt was considered an Olympic favorite in a winter sport she had never tried.
content: Follow our live coverage of the 2022 Winter Olympics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman
title: Pandemic’s Economic Impact Is Easing, but Aftershocks May Linger
description: States are lifting mask mandates, and demand is bouncing back quickly after Omicron. Supply constraints are proving harder to escape.
content: The pandemic’s grip on the economy appears to be loosening. Job growth and retail spending were strong in January, even as coronavirus cases hit a record. New York, Massachusetts and other states have begun to lift indoor mask mandates. California on Thursday unveiled a public health approach that will treat the coronavirus as a manageable long-term risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Lauren Hirsch
title: Peloton’s New C.E.O. on the Tough Road Ahead
description: Barry McCarthy replaced the floundering company’s founder as chief executive this month. In an interview with DealBook, Mr. McCarthy discussed what he plans to do differently.
content: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in business. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: After Mounting a Comeback, Eagles Face a New Threat
description: A study of hundreds of bald eagles and golden eagles showed that nearly half of them had chronic lead poisoning.
content: The bald eagle, whose resurgence is considered one of the great conservation success stories of the 21st century, is facing a serious threat: lead poisoning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: What’s new for the next Winter Olympics? Ski mountaineering.
description: It’s sort of like Alpine skiing, except the athletes start the race by climbing to the top of the mountain under their own power.
content: Do you watch Alpine skiing and say, “Big deal — they take a ski lift up the mountain”? If so, ski mountaineering is for you. And in four years, you’ll be able to watch it in the Olympics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariro Mzezewa
title: After Calling One Witness, Defense Rests in Arbery Hate Crimes Trial
description: A federal jury will hear closing arguments on Monday and then determine whether the three men convicted of Ahmaud Arbery’s murder killed him because he was Black.
content: BRUNSWICK, Ga. — Defense lawyers in the hate crimes trial of the three white men convicted of murdering Ahmaud Arbery rested their case on Friday after calling just a single witness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell and Leah Askarinam
title: Explaining Putin’s Decades-Long Obsession With Ukraine
description: We spoke with Fiona Hill, a former Trump adviser, about how the Russian leader’s view of history has led him to the brink of war.
content: Winston Churchill once described Russia as “a riddle, wrapped in a mystery, inside an enigma.” It’s a phrase that could equally apply to Vladimir Putin, the Kremlin’s leader, as the world awaits his next move on Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Fisher
title: Putin’s Baseless Claims of Genocide Hint at More Than War
description: The invocations serve to justify not just Moscow’s actions in Ukraine, but also its wider quest for a new imperial identity rooted in Russian ethnicity.
content: Moscow, in another escalation toward a possible invasion of Ukraine, is issuing a growing drumbeat of accusations, all without evidence, that center on a single word.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley
title: China’s foreign minister calls for new negotiations and respect for ‘territorial integrity.’
description: China’s foreign minister, Wang Yi, called on Saturday for fresh negotiations to avoid major conflict over Ukraine, arguing that a set of moribund cease-fire agreements from 2014-15 could form the basis for a deal.
content: China’s foreign minister, Wang Yi, called on Saturday for fresh negotiations to avoid major conflict over Ukraine, arguing that a set of moribund cease-fire agreements from 2014-15 could form the basis for a deal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Fringe Scheme to Reverse 2020 Election Splits Wisconsin G.O.P.
description: False claims that Donald J. Trump can be reinstalled in the White House are picking up steam — and spiraling further from reality as they go.
content: MADISON, Wis. — First, Wisconsin Republicans ordered an audit of the 2020 election. Then they passed a raft of new restrictions on voting. And in June, they authorized the nation’s only special counsel investigation into 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: Once He Kept Russia at a Distance. Now He Is a Docile Putin Satrap.
description: President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus once skillfully managed Moscow, but now he is doing the Kremlin’s bidding in Russia’s confrontation with Ukraine.
content: MINSK, Belarus — In a winter military coat trimmed with fur, Aleksandr G. Lukashenko stepped out of his white presidential helicopter for a morning of geopolitical theater. His presidential limousine quickly delivered him to his waiting generals as aides and heavily armed bodyguards fluttered around him, shivering in the icy rain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Randal C. Archibold
title: Sweden’s men win the curling gold at last.
description: The Swedes lost the top medal to the United States four years ago.
content: Four years ago, the Swedish men’s curling team watched as a team of Americans exulted in winning their country’s first curling gold. It was a bitter upset they did not forget.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: How much does a bobsled weigh?
description: Each division of the sledding events at the Games requires a different weight for the sled.
content: Bobsled is one of the most watched events in the Winter Games, but the intricacies of the sport remain a bit of a mystery to some — for instance, how much do they actually weigh?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Arraf
title: Conflict and Climate Change Ravage Syria’s Agricultural Heartland
description: Drought and a decade of war have brought failing crops and poverty to a region once known as Syria’s breadbasket. Even the bread has changed.
content: HASAKA, Syria — At a government bakery in Hasaka, Syria, a faded image of former President Hafez al-Assad looms over the aging machinery and clanging steel chains of the assembly line. The painting dates from long before the war, when this region of northeast Syria was still under government control.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliet Macur
title: A Chinese pair’s gold completes a tumultuous two weeks for figure skating.
description: Sui Wenjing and Han Cong of China won the gold medal in pairs figure skating on Saturday at Capital Indoor Stadium in Beijing, capping two scandal-tinged, mistake-marred, tear-stained weeks for a signature Olympic sport with a nearly flawless performance.
content: Sui Wenjing and Han Cong of China won the gold medal in pairs figure skating on Saturday at Capital Indoor Stadium in Beijing, capping two scandal-tinged, mistake-marred, tear-stained weeks for a signature Olympic sport with a nearly flawless performance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins, Andrew E. Kramer and Ivan Nechepurenko
title: ‘Be Calm,’ He Said, as Mortar Shells Fell on the Road Behind Us
description: As shelling intensified in eastern Ukraine, a seemingly routine press tour turned into a frantic rush to safety.
content: NOVOLUHANSKE, Ukraine — “Be calm,” Denis, the 28-year-old driver said, after several mortar shells landed on the road behind us. As we sought cover inside the local army headquarters, another half-dozen mortar shells exploded around us.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: 3 Types of Baby Formula Recalled After Reported Bacterial Infections
description: Abbott Nutrition issued voluntary recalls of their popular Similac, Alimentum and EleCare formulas after four infants were hospitalized with bacterial infections.
content: Abbott Nutrition, a popular baby food manufacturer, announced on Thursday that it was voluntarily recalling three types of infant formula after four babies became sick with bacterial infections after consuming the products.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Intense shelling rocks eastern Ukraine.
description: SEVERODONETSK, Ukraine — Several intense artillery barrages by Russia-backed separatists on Saturday targeted a pocket of Ukrainian government-controlled territory around the town of Svitlodarsk, a spot that has worried security analysts for weeks because of its proximity to industrial infrastructure, including storage tanks for poisonous gas.
content: SEVERODONETSK, Ukraine — Several intense artillery barrages by Russia-backed separatists on Saturday targeted a pocket of Ukrainian government-controlled territory around the town of Svitlodarsk, a spot that has worried security analysts for weeks because of its proximity to industrial infrastructure, including storage tanks for poisonous gas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jasper Craven
title: When the Heart Belongs to Carhartt
description: A beloved store in a small hometown closes, but the residents still need their work wear.
content: For more than 14 months, Gary Ely has quietly shown up for a job he no longer has at Caplan’s Army Store in St. Johnsbury, Vt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear, Valerie Hopkins, Marc Santora and Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Biden Says Putin Has Chosen ‘Catastrophic’ War Over Diplomacy
description: President Biden spoke amid fears that Russia was setting the stage for an invasion that could ignite the biggest conflict in Europe in decades.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden said on Friday that the United States has intelligence showing that President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia has made a final decision to reject diplomatic overtures and invade Ukraine, in what Mr. Biden said would be a “catastrophic and needless war of choice” in Eastern Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sian Beilock
title: Mikaela Shiffrin Stumbled. What Happens Next Matters More.
description: The experience of choking in high-pressure situations can often feel like an out-of-body experience. That’s because in some ways, it is.
content: Watching a two-time Olympian and three-time Olympic medalist skier stumble — not once, not twice, but three times — at the Beijing Olympics was both extraordinary and painfully ordinary. No matter how well we prepare ourselves, how focused we are, what mental exercises we do to get ready, the reality is: These things happen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall
title: Soaring Energy Bills Deepen Crisis for Turks, and Erdogan
description: Hit by spiraling inflation, electricity bills have doubled for households and businesses in only a month.
content: ISTANBUL — It began with a few outraged customers posting photographs of their electricity bills to social media, showing how charges had almost doubled at the end of January. But such complaints have quickly snowballed into a full-blown political crisis for the government of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Kitroeff and Sarah Maslin Nir
title: Ottawa Protesters Cleared From Parliament Encampment
description: A central area of the protest that roiled Canada’s capital for three weeks was cleared of demonstrators.
content: OTTAWA — Police officers on Saturday cleared out the central area of a sprawling demonstration in Ottawa, moving from truck to truck and arresting protesters as they continued to subdue the occupation that has disrupted the Canadian capital for weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aina J. Khan
title: Storm Eunice Unleashes Fierce Winds in Northern Europe, Killing at Least 8
description: Gusts toppled trees and sent debris flying, leaving tens of thousands without power and disrupting travel a day later.
content: LONDON — Tens of thousands of homes were without power on Saturday, a day after a severe storm pummeled parts of Britain and northern Europe, killing at least eight people, damaging buildings and causing major travel disruptions across the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Pardon My French
description: Prepare to feel the satisfaction of finishing this Sunday puzzle by Victor Barocas. Why? Because it’s un oeuf.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Bienvenue, everyone! This is Victor Barocas’s ninth Sunday crossword puzzle for The Times, and his 17th overall. He favors these big grids and hides some truly mind-blowing tricks in them, having to do with, say, scientific measurements or gene splicing. This is fitting because this constructor is also a professor of biomedical engineering at the University of Minnesota as well as a longtime member of the National Puzzlers’ League and a contributor to its monthly publication, “The Enigma.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esther Horvath and Henry Fountain
title: The Search Has Begun for an Antarctic Pioneer’s Lost Ship
description: Explorers have started combing the Weddell Sea for one of the most revered ships in the history of polar exploration, Ernest Shackleton’s Endurance, which sank in 1915.
content: The hunt is on for Endurance, Ernest Shackleton’s ship that sits 10,000 feet below the icy Weddell Sea in Antarctica.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliet Macur, Chang W. Lee and Doug Mills
title: An Exclamation Point for China, Delivered by the Finest of Margins
description: Sui Wenjing and Han Cong won the pairs figure skating competition, producing a gold for their country and capping two weeks of artistry and tumult for their sport.
content: Follow our live coverage of the 2022 Winter Olympics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Weiyi Cai, Eleanor Lutz, Emily Rhyne, Joe Ward and Jeremy White
title: Moments From the Beijing Winter Games, Frame by Frame
description: See the Winter Olympics in a series of composite images.
content: See the Winter Olympics in a series of composite images.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval
title: Young Voters Weigh a Texas District's Future
description: Once a Democratic stronghold, the 28th Congressional District, which includes Laredo, has become a battleground race.
content: Once a Democratic stronghold, the 28th Congressional District, which includes Laredo, has become a battleground race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Josh Keller
title: How Long Covid Exhausts the Body
description: A picture is emerging of the toll long Covid takes inside the body and why it can be so debilitating.
content: A picture is emerging of the toll long Covid takes inside the body and why it can be so debilitating.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yousur Al-Hlou, Masha Froliak, Brent McDonald and Dmitriy Khavin
title: The Ukrainian Paramilitaries Ready to Fight Russia
description: The New York Times traveled with a paramilitary group that says it refuses to leave the front lines in Ukraine’s war in the east. But the government denies that they’re even there. What role can they have in a larger conflict with Russia?
content: The New York Times traveled with a paramilitary group that says it refuses to leave the front lines in Ukraine’s war in the east. But the government denies that they’re even there. What role can they have in a larger conflict with Russia?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By SARAH NIR and Reuters
title: Ottawa Police Clash With Protesters
description: Police officers made dozens of arrests as they moved to clear protesters from the streets of the Canadian capital where a truck blockade had been disrupting daily life for weeks.
content: Police officers made dozens of arrests as they moved to clear protesters from the streets of the Canadian capital where a truck blockade had been disrupting daily life for weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Aiken
title: ‘I Identify as an Angler’: Meet Erica Nelson, a Female, Indigenous Fly Fishing Guide
description: She hooks tree branches, slips on rocks, and shines a light on the topics nobody talks about in her sport.
content: “I admit it,” says Erica Nelson, one of just two female Indigenous fly fishing guides in Colorado, “I’m awkward.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Feb. 19, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Feb. 19, 2022.
content: An article on Monday about the history of lox misstated the clue for LOX in the Feb. 7 crossword. The clue is “bagels and ___,” not “Schmear topper.” The error was repeated in the headline.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Divisions Among U.S. Evangelicals
description: Readers discuss how racial and sexual issues and Donald Trump have led to strife and whether and how evangelism should be saved.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
